Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Drosophila Ultraconserved Elements: Function and Evolution

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: Comparative genomics, as a field, aims to identify functional regions in the genomes of plants and animals by comparing entire genomic DNA sequences. These bioinformatic comparisons have revealed regions of genomes that are highly conserved over long evolutionary times, yet little is known regarding their function. Most of these highly conserved DNA sequences occur in non-protein coding regions of genomes. This project aims to elucidate the function and evolution of the most slowly evolving portions of the Drosophila (fruit fly) genome. Because they are so highly conserved, it is anticipated these regions of the Drosophila genome have important functions. Fruit flies will be studied because they can be experimentally manipulated using sophisticated genetic and molecular methods. This project is a collaborative effort led by computational biologist Andrew Kern, responsible for the bioinformatic aspects of the research, and by geneticist Daniel Barbash, responsible for the experimental studies.

Broader Impacts: Dr. Kern will collaborate with Nancy Serrell, the Director of Dartmouth College's Office of Outreach, to identify interested high school science teachers in the local area and coordinate organization of on-site, hands-on workshops for high school students. The project will use a "cascade" approach to bring computational biological methods into the high school classroom. Dr. Kern will collaborate with local high school teachers to develop, test, and refine lesson plans, which will be implemented in high school classrooms with assistance from graduate and undergraduate students in the Kern Lab. Lesson plans will provide students with significant hands-on applications comparing genomes using bioinformatic programs and web-based analysis tools. Dr. Barbash will train undergraduate researchers in experimental design, research methods, and data analysis to participate in the Drosophila genetics research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A fundamental observation in comparing genomes among species is that certain portions of the genome appear to be conserved over very long stretches of evolutionary time. While variation in levels of sequence conservation across the genome has been leveraged as a signal to recognize functional portions of genomes, we know surprisingly little about the most conserved sequences in the genome, the so-called ultraconserved regions. This research project aimed at elucidating some of the biological roles of ultraconserved elements in Drosophila (fruit flies) using a combination of computational and molecular biological techniques.

 

Our results from Drosophila ultraconserved elements found that these genomic elements were evolving incredibly slowly between species because natural selection was removing nearly all new mutations from populations. Thus we can infer that our ultraconserved elements were doing something very important for the organism, however we are unsure as to what. To answer this question we turned to computational predictions of function in our set of ultraconserved elements. We identified a group of novel non-coding RNA genes (ncRNAs), that are genes that produce functional RNA molecules rather than proteins. This research grant allowed us to begin to explore the patterns of expression of these ncRNAs. In addition we attempted to manipulate the expression of the novel ncRNAs using an inferring RNA technique, but were ultimately unsuccessful.

 

During the course of this research we also developed and applied computational methods that were aimed at discovering functional regions of genomes using a combination of sequence conservation information between species and within-population genetic variation information. These techniques led to interesting characterizations of the landscape of conservation in plant genomes, as well in human genomes.

 

In general, this grant led to the publication of seven scientific papers, and contributed to the training of two postdoctoral scholars, two graduate students, undergraduate students, and a number high school and middle school students.
